results.byline: By Soumya Karlamangla and Shawn Hubler
results.title: Tulare Lake Was Drained Off the Map. Nature Would Like a Word.
results.abstract: A barrage of storms has resurrected what was once the largest body of fresh water west of the Mississippi River, setting the stage for a disaster this spring.

media.caption: Roads and farms are being flooded outside Corcoran, Calif., where the vast Tulare Lake once existed.
media.copyright: Mark Abramson for The New York Times

results.title: Ending Your Pet’s Life Was the Right Decision. So Why Do You Feel So Guilty?
results.abstract: As a veterinarian, I counseled many people through the end of a beloved pet’s life. But when my cat got sick, it started a whole new journey.

results.title: Hoping to Travel Abroad? Don’t Put Off Your Passport Application.
results.abstract: Processing times for new and renewed passports have increased again. The updated timeline, 10 to 13 weeks, leaves some would-be travelers feeling desperate.

media.caption: A passport being stamped at John F. Kennedy International Airport in New York.

results.adx_keywords: Referendums;Electric Bicycles, Motorcycles and Scooters;Hidalgo, Anne (1959- );Paris (France)
results.title: In Paris Referendum, 89% of Voters Back a Ban on Electric Scooters
results.abstract: A referendum emphasized how many residents had come to regard the scooters as dangerous nuisances with little environmental benefit. Other cities were closely watching the vote.

media.caption: Relatively few people turned out for the referendum about the scooters — only about 100,000 Parisians voted, less than 7.5 percent of those eligible — but nearly 89 percent backed the ban.

results.title: Colleges Should Be More Than Just Vocational Schools
results.abstract: Elected officials have pushed vocational programs at the expense of the liberal arts. That’s hurting America.

results.adx_keywords: Eyes and Eyesight;Factories and Manufacturing;Bacteria;Deaths (Fatalities);Antibiotics;Infections;Medicine and Health;Recalls and Bans of Products
results.byline: By Christina Jewett and Andrew Jacobs
results.title: Drug-Resistant Bacteria Tied to Eyedrops Can Spread Person to Person
results.abstract: The C.D.C. traced deaths and cases of blindness to products imported from India. The agency said it was concerned that the bacteria could gain a foothold in the U.S.

media.caption: EzriCare artificial tears contaminated with an antibiotic-resistant bacteria have been linked to an outbreak affecting 68 patients in 16 states. Of those, eight have lost their vision, four lost an eye and three have died.
media.copyright: Melanie Metz for The New York Times

results.abstract: We’re living in a world where the sanctuaries are actually prisons.

results.adx_keywords: Sauces;Condiments;Korean Food (Cuisine)
results.title: Gochujang Is So Much More Than a Condiment
results.abstract: In Korean cooking, it’s a foundational ingredient, and just the beginning of an endless assortment of delicious meals.

media.caption: Gochujang, the Korean fermented red pepper paste, is thick and glossy with a spicy savoriness that lingers. Thin it out with soy sauce and vinegar to create a gochujang sauce, or swirl it into brown sugar and butter for cookies.
media.copyright: James Ransom for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Barrett Washburne.

results.adx_keywords: Happiness;Optimism;Politics and Government;Badminton;vis-photo;Finland
results.byline: By Penelope Colston and Jake Michaels
results.title: The Finnish Secret to Happiness? Knowing When You Have Enough.
results.abstract: The Nordic nation has been ranked the happiest country on earth for six consecutive years. But when you talk to individual Finns, the reality is a bit more complicated.

media.caption: Henna and Niklas Hukari, siblings who play badminton in the rural community of Toholampi, are among more than a dozen Finns we spoke with about how optimism manifests in their lives.
media.copyright: Jake Michaels for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Books and Literature;Content Type: Personal Profile;Philosophy;Writing and Writers;Religion and Belief;Bakewell, Sarah;England
results.title: For Sarah Bakewell, Nothing Human is Alien
results.abstract: In “Humanly Possible,” Bakewell brings her signature blend of wit and philosophical sophistication to the complex, sometimes contentious 700-year history of humanist thought.

media.caption: Sarah Bakewell’s new book, “Humanly Possible” tackles nothing less than the grand humanist project, but remains, fundamentally, sunny, companionable, let’s-get-along book, in keeping with Bakewell’s own temperament.
media.copyright: Tom Jamieson for The New York Times

results.title: A Front Company and a Fake Identity: How the U.S. Came to Use Spyware It Was Trying to Kill.
results.abstract: The Biden administration has been trying to choke off use of hacking tools made by the Israeli firm NSO. It turns out that not every part of the government has gotten the message.
